awd_titl_txt: Individuating and comparing objects and events
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary mode by which we communicate our ideas about the world and about each other is through language. However, languages aren't merely passive vehicles for the transmission of information. Rather, our sentences carry along with them evidence of the fundamental concepts and categories that we use to understand the world and each other. At one level, this fact about language might seem obvious: a person on one side of an argument might choose to use words that a person on a different side might not, and attending to these different choices tells us something about the people speaking. Such observations about language and language users are studied in fields like sociolinguistics. Yet, our language also reveals more basic truths about us which are not as easily accessible to consciousness, and which are more tied to elements of our common experience. For example, people talk as if there are objects that can be counted ("four spoons") and substances that cannot (e.g., "four muds" is odd), even if arranged in discrete piles. Investigating language at this deeper level can thus reveal basic structures of thought, informing theories of cognition and its development, as well as applications in artificial intelligence.

This project studies parallels in the conceptualization of the basic categories 'object' and 'event' as they are encoded in language and understood by both adults and 4 year olds. Previous research in linguistics and the philosophy of language has uncovered striking formal parallels in the encoding of these categories across nominal and verbal language. The project links this research to what is known about object representation in cognitive science, and uses this link to extend what is known about event representation. Specifically, the project (i) tests whether the observed linguistic parallels correspond to parallels in how adults and children conceptualize minimally-different static and dynamic scenes, (ii) investigates the extent to which representational biases for simple dynamic scenes predicts how adults and children understand quantificational language involving words like "more", and (iii) probes the hypothetical universality of the language-cognition linkages by teaching English-speaking adults and children attested, but non-English patterns of event encoding. The results of this project will demonstrate the fruitfulness of connecting formal semantics, philosophy of language, and cognitive science to illuminate the interface between linguistic and non-linguistic perception and cognition.

por.por_cntn:
Linguists say that sentences are about events, but what does that mean? This project focuses on the properties of the language that adults and children use to talk about events, and how it compares to talk of objects. The project engages interdisciplinary ideas from the fields of linguistics, philosophy of language and mind, and cognitive psychology to better understand how minds like ours fundamentally represent and reason about this important and understudied category of everyday experience. Importantly, while people can and will disagree about whether a given event occurred, what kind of event occurred, and who was responsible for it, deciding whether or not something counts as an event is typically not up for debate. Studying how people understand events can thus provide a unique window into our shared human nature.

Centered in findings from formal semantics, the project focused on addressing whether and how proposals from linguistics can be used to extend what we know about how ordinary people represent events, how these representations are similar to or different from how they represent objects, and how the interpretation of quantificational words like "more" interacts with event representations across development. We made substantial progress on each of these questions, while also providing demonstrating the utility of 'cognitivizing' the linguistic theory. The project reveals that, whether college student or preschooler, people understand 'events' to be dynamic, coherent wholes which may occur in discrete pluralities. Such a category of temporal entity contrasts fundamentally with 'processes' which we understand as dynamic, undifferentiated activity. 

A wealth of evidence in cognitive psychology and cognitive development has borne out the idea that a parallel distinction between 'object' and 'substance' is robust, and broadly continuous between infants, preschoolers, and adults, as revealed by how people understand sentences with "more". So far, the project has provided the first evidence that (i) the formal features defining the relevant representations in people?s cognizance of the 'static' domain replicate in the dynamic domain, for example 'cumulativity', 'divisiveness', and the notion of a non-arbitrary whole, and (ii) providing scenes inviting satisfaction of the relevant featural values correctly predicts how people understand new verbs that they hear for the first time, and consequently which dimension for comparison they selection asked what counts as "more" of it. 

The project has had a significant impact within and beyond the scientific and philosophical literatures to which it contributes. The project presents a way of thinking about proposals in the formal semantics literature that supports leveraging them towards what we know, in a robust way, about how people think. The success of this method should, thereby, encourage more cognitive scientists to consider formal semantic and metaphysical description as a rich source for cognitive hypotheses, and encourage more semanticists to think of their theories as illuminating the structure of mental representation. The project supported workshops and the development of new pedagogy.  And, it directly supported research experiences and training for 19 students (2 graduate students, 17 undergraduate students) drawn from a highly diverse pool (11 women; 15 non-white).
